revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Les_Premières_funérailles_-_Louis-Ernest_Barrias_(B_837).jpg|thumb]] '''''The First Funeral''''' is an 1878 plaster sculpture by [[Louis-Ernest Barrias]] (1841-1905), first exhibited at the [[Paris Salon]] that year, where it won a medal of honour. He then produced a marble version for the Salon of 1883. Both works showing [[Adam and Eve]] bearing the body of their son [[Abel]]. The plaster original is now in the [[Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon]].
==Sources== *http://www.petitpalais.paris.fr/oeuvre/les-premieres-funerailles
{{DEFAULTSORT:First Funeral}} {{Sculpture-stub}} [[category:1870s sculptures]] [[category:Sculptures of the Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon]] [[category:Plaster sculptures]] [[category:Sculptures depicting Hebrew Bible people]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Adam and Eve]] [[Category:Death in art]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Cain and Abel]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox film | name = The Ghost Writer | image = The Ghost Writer poster.png | caption = US film poster | director = [[Roman Polanski]] | producer = Roman Polanski
Robert Benmussa
[[Alain Sarde]] | screenplay = [[Robert Harris (novelist)|Robert Harris]]
Roman Polanski | based on = {{based on|''[[The Ghost (novel)|The Ghost]]''|Robert Harris}} | starring = [[Ewan McGregor]]
[[Pierce Brosnan]]
[[Kim Cattrall]]
[[Olivia Williams]]
[[Tom Wilkinson]]
[[Timothy Hutton]]
[[Jon Bernthal]]
[[Tim Preece]]
[[Robert Pugh]]
[[David Rintoul]]
[[Eli Wallach]] | music = [[Alexandre Desplat]] | cinematography = [[Paweł Edelman]] | editing = [[Hervé de Luze]] | distributor = [[Summit Entertainment]] (United States)
[[Optimum Releasing]] (United Kingdom) | released = {{Film date|df=y|2010|02|12|[[Berlin Film Festival]]|2010|2|18|Germany|2010|03|03|France|2010|04|16|United Kingdom}} | runtime = 128 minutes | country = United Kingdom
France
Germany | language = English | budget = $45 million{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=theghostwriter.htm | title=The Ghost Writer (2010) | publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] | accessdate=26 August 2010}} | gross = $60.2 million }} '''''The Ghost Writer''''' (released as '''''The Ghost''''' in the United Kingdom and Ireland)[https://archive.is/20120903163937/http://www.movies.ie/articles/free_preview_screening__the_ghost Movies.ie 6 April 2010: "Free Preview Screening the Ghost in Dublin"]. Retrieved 30 January 2012 is a 2010 Franco-German-British [[political thriller]] film directed by [[Roman Polanski]]. The film is an adaptation of a [[Robert Harris (novelist)|Robert Harris]] novel, ''[[The Ghost (Harris novel)|The Ghost]]'', with the screenplay written by Polanski and Harris. It stars [[Ewan McGregor]], [[Pierce Brosnan]], [[Kim Cattrall]] and [[Olivia Williams]].[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1139328/ IMDb: The Ghost Writer main details]. Retrieved 30 January 2012 The film was a critical and commercial success and won numerous cinematic awards including Best Director for Polanski at the [[60th Berlin International Film Festival]] and also at the [[23rd European Film Awards]] in 2010.{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/dec/05/roman-polanski-film-ghost-writer | title=Roman Polanski film The Ghost Writer dominates European awards | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=5 December 2010 | accessdate=14 April 2014 | last=Brooks | first=Xan}} ==Plot== A British [[ghostwriter]] ([[Ewan McGregor]]) is hired by the [[Publishing|publishing firm]] Rhinehart, Inc., to complete the autobiography of former [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] Adam Lang ([[Pierce Brosnan]]). His predecessor and Lang's aide, Mike McAra, has recently died in an apparent drowning accident. The writer travels to Old Haven on [[Martha's Vineyard]], [[Massachusetts]], where Lang and his wife Ruth ([[Olivia Williams]]) are staying, along with Lang's personal assistant (and implied mistress), Amelia Bly ([[Kim Cattrall]]). Amelia forbids the writer from taking McAra's [[Manuscript format|manuscript]] outside, emphasising that it is a security risk. Shortly after the writer's arrival, former [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] Richard Rycart ([[Robert Pugh]]) accuses Lang of authorising the [[extraordinary rendition|illegal seizure]] of suspected terrorists and handing them over for [[torture]] by the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]], a possible [[war crime]]. Lang faces prosecution by the [[International Criminal Court]] unless he stays in the US (or one of the few other countries that does not recognise the court's jurisdiction). While Lang is in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]], the writer finds items in McAra's room suggesting he might have stumbled across a dark secret. Among them is an envelope containing photographs and a phone number the writer discovers is Rycart's. During a bike ride, the writer encounters an old man ([[Eli Wallach]]) who tells him the current couldn't have taken McAra's body from the ferry where he disappeared to the beach where it was discovered. He also reveals a neighbour saw flashlights on the beach the night McAra died, but later fell down the stairs and went into a coma. Later, Ruth admits to the writer Lang had never been very political, and until recently always took her advice. When he tells her the old man's story, she suddenly rushes out into the rainy night to "clear her head." Upon returning, she reveals Lang and McAra had argued the night before the latter's death, and the ghost writer and Ruth have a [[one night stand]] while Adam is away. The next morning, the writer takes the [[BMW X5 (E70)|BMW X5]]2009 BMW X5 xDrive30d [E70] in The Ghost Writer, Movie, 2010 http://www.imcdb.org/vehicle_325926-BMW-X5-E70-2009.html McAra used on his last journey. Unable to cancel the pre-programmed directions on the car's [[Satellite navigation|sat-nav]], he decides to follow them. He arrives in [[Belmont, Massachusetts|Belmont]] at the home of Professor Paul Emmett ([[Tom Wilkinson]]). Emmett denies anything more than a cursory acquaintance with Lang, despite the writer showing him two pictures of the pair among photographs found in McAra's possessions, as well as another on the wall of Emmett's study. When the writer tells Emmett the sat-nav proves McAra visited him the night he died, Emmett denies meeting McAra and becomes evasive. The writer leaves, and successfully eludes a car that is pursuing him. He boards the ferry back to Martha's Vineyard, but when he sees the pursuit car drive aboard, he flees the boat at the last moment and checks into a small motel by the ferry dock. With no one else to turn to, the writer redials Rycart's number, asking for help. While waiting, the writer does research on Emmett and links his [[think tank]] to a [[Arms industry|military contractor]]. He also finds leads connecting Emmett to the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]]. When Rycart arrives, he reveals McAra [[News leak|gave him]] documents linking Lang to so-called "torture flights," where terrorist suspects were placed on private jets owned by Emmett's company, to be tortured while airborne. Rycart further claims that McAra found new evidence, which he wrote about in the "beginning" of the manuscript. The men cannot, however, find anything in the early pages. The writer discusses Emmett's relationship with Lang, while Rycart recounts how Lang's decisions as Prime Minister uniformly benefited US interests. When the writer is summoned to accompany Lang on his return flight by private jet, he confronts Lang and accuses him of being a CIA agent recruited by Emmett. Lang derides his suggestions. Upon leaving the aircraft, Lang is assassinated by a British [[Anti-war movement|anti-war]] protester, who is in turn shot by Lang's bodyguards. Nevertheless, the writer is asked to complete the book for posthumous publication, as in light of Lang's death it will be a certain best-seller. Amelia invites him to the book's launch party in London, where she unwittingly tells him the Americans tightened access to the book, as the "beginnings" contained evidence threatening national security. She also tells him Emmett, who is in attendance, was Ruth's tutor when she was a [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright scholar]] at [[Harvard University|Harvard]]. The writer realizes the clues were hidden in the original manuscript in the opening words of each paragraph, and discovers the message: "Lang's wife Ruth was recruited as a CIA agent by Professor Paul Emmett of Harvard University." He concludes Ruth shaped Lang's every political decision to benefit the USA under direction from the CIA. The writer passes a note to Ruth revealing his discovery. She unfolds the note, and is devastated. When she sees the writer raising a glass, she is kept from following him by Emmett and other assistants. As the writer leaves the party he attempts to take a taxi, without success. As he crosses the street off-camera, a car accelerates in his direction to an impending collision. As witnesses react in horror, the pages containing McAra's manuscript are blowing in the wind, leaving the writer's fate unconfirmed. ==Cast== * [[Ewan McGregor]] as The Ghost, an unnamed [[ghostwriter]]. * [[Pierce Brosnan]] as Adam Peter Bennett Lang, a former [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]]. * [[Olivia Williams]] as Ruth Lang, Lang's wife. * [[Kim Cattrall]] as Amelia Bly, Lang's personal assistant. * [[Timothy Hutton]] as Sidney Kroll, Lang's American lawyer. * [[Tom Wilkinson]] as Paul Emmett, a professor at [[Harvard Law School]]. * [[Jon Bernthal]] as Rick Ricardelli, the ghostwriter's [[Literary agent|agent]]. * [[Jim Belushi|James Belushi]] as John Maddox, Rhinehart's [[New York City|New York]] executive. * [[Robert Pugh]] as Richard Rycart, UN Envoy and former British [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|foreign secretary]]. * [[Tim Preece]] as Roy Quigley, managing director of Rhinehart's [[London]] business. * [[David Rintoul]] as The Stranger, a grieving father who lost his son during the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|War in Afghanistan]]. * [[Eli Wallach]] as The Old Man at Martha's Vineyard. ===Non-fictional allusions=== Pierce Brosnan plays the character of Adam Lang, who has echoes of former British Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]]. The character is linked to the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]], the [[war on terror]] and the [[Special Relationship|special relationship with the United States]]. The author of the book on which the film is based has said he was inspired at least in part by anger at Mr Blair's policies, and calls for him to face war crimes trials.{{cite news|author=[[Barbara Plett]]|date=19 March 2010| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/8576156.stm|title=How Realistic Is New Polanski Film The Ghost?|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate= 5 March 2011}} Robert Pugh, who portrayed the British Foreign Secretary, Richard Rycart, and Mo Asumang, who played the US Secretary of State, both physically resemble their real-life counterparts, [[Robin Cook]] and [[Condoleezza Rice]]. Like the fictional Rycart, Cook had foreign policy differences with the British Prime Minister. The old man living on Martha's Vineyard is a reference to [[Robert McNamara]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/apr/18/the-ghost-roman-polanski-review |title=The Ghost—Roman Polanski's Immaculately Crafted Adaptation of Robert Harris's Bestseller Is a Chilling and Sinister Study of Power|work=[[The Observer]]|author=[[Philip French|French, Philip]] |date=18 April 2010|accessdate=5 March 2011 |quote=''Oddly, as co-adaptors, Polanski and Harris have played down a character carefully signalled in the book. In the film, the 94-year-old Eli Wallach plays an elderly Vineyard resident who gives the ghost writer some vital information concerning the cove where the previous writer's corpse washed up. In the novel, he is clearly identified as the former secretary of state Robert McNamara by his rimless glasses and hairstyle, his statement about war crimes ("We could all have been charged with those. Maybe we should have been.") and a reference to a real event in 1972: "Hell, a guy tried to throw me off that damn ferry when I was still at the World Bank." This explains Harris's curious, ludic choice of the name McAra for the original ghost in the novel.''|location=London}} Hatherton Corporation alludes to real-life Halliburton. ==Production== Polanski had originally teamed with Robert Harris for a film of Harris's novel ''[[Pompeii (novel)|Pompeii]]'',[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117958517?refCatId=13 Variety 1 February 2007: Polanski propels 'Pompeii']. Retrieved 30 January 2012 but the project was cancelled because of the looming actors' strike that autumn.[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/news/1670046/roman_polanski_flees_pompeii/ Rotten Tomatoes 12 September 2007: Roman Polanski Flees Pompeii]. Retrieved 30 January 2012{{cite web|author=Mr. Beaks|url=http://www.aintitcool.com/node/44177|title=Mr. Beaks Interrogates The Ghost Writer Novelist-Screenwriter Robert Harris!|work=[[Ain't It Cool News]]|date=5 March 2010|accessdate=5 March 2011}} Polanski and Harris then turned to Harris' current best seller, ''[[The Ghost (Harris novel)|The Ghost]]''. They co-wrote a script and in November 2007, just after the book's release, Polanski announced filming for autumn 2008.{{cite news| url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117975536?refCatId=13|work=Variety|first=Tatiana|last=Siegel|title=Roman Polanski returns with 'Ghost'|date=7 November 2007}} In June 2008, [[Nicolas Cage]], [[Pierce Brosnan]], [[Tilda Swinton]], and [[Kim Cattrall]] were announced as the stars.{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117988074?refCatId=13|work=Variety|first=Michael | last=Fleming|title=Cage, Brosnan see Polanski's 'Ghost'| date=25 June 2008}} Production was then postponed by a number of months, with [[Ewan McGregor]] and [[Olivia Williams]] replacing Cage and Swinton, respectively, as a result. [[File:The Ghostwriter - ferry.jpg|thumb|The North Sea ferry MS ''SyltExpress'' that was used as the Martha's Vineyard ferry in the film.]] The film finally began production in February 2009 in Germany, at the [[Babelsberg Studios]] in [[Potsdam]]. Germany stood in for London and [[Martha's Vineyard]] due to Polanski's inability to legally travel to those places, as Polanski had fled the U.S. in 1978 after pleading guilty to [[Roman Polanski sexual abuse case|unlawful sex with a 13-year-old girl]]. The majority of exteriors, set on Martha's Vineyard, were shot on the island of [[Sylt]] in the North Sea, and on the ferry MS ''SyltExpress''. The exterior set of the house where much of the film takes place, however, was built on the island of [[Usedom]], in the Baltic Sea. Exteriors and interiors set at a publishing house in London were shot at Charlottenstrasse 47 in downtown [[Berlin]] (Mitte), while [[Strausberg|Strausberg Airport]] near Berlin stood in for the Vineyard airport.[[Database]] (undated). [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1139328/locations "Filming Locations for The Ghost Writer (2010)"]. ''[[Internet Movie Database]]''. Retrieved 5 March 2011. A few brief exterior shots for driving scenes were shot by a second unit in Massachusetts, without Polanski or the actors.The end credits list Wellfleet, Provincetown and Bourne, Massachusetts On his way to the [[Zurich Film Festival]], Polanski was [[Roman Polanski sexual abuse case|arrested by Swiss police]] in September 2009 at the request of the US and held for extradition on a 1978 arrest warrant. Due to Polanski's arrest, post-production was briefly put on hold, but he resumed and completed work from house arrest at his Swiss villa. He was unable to participate in the film's [[world premiere]] at the [[Berlinale]] festival on 12 February 2010.{{cite news|author1=Verschuur, Paul |author2=Pettersson, Edvard |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601088&sid=acnp0zi_Edgw|title=Polanski Arrested in Switzerland on 1978 U.S. Warrant (Correct)|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=28 September 2009|accessdate=5 March 2011}} ==Release== The film premièred at the [[60th Berlin International Film Festival]] on 12 February 2010,[http://www.berlinale.de/en/programm/berlinale_programm/datenblatt.php?film_id=20100164 Berlin Film Festival Program] and was widely released throughout much of Europe during the following four weeks. It went on general release in the US on 19 March 2010 and in the UK on 16 April 2010.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1139328/releaseinfo IMDb: Release dates for The Ghost Writer]. Retrieved 30 January 2012 ==Reception== The film has received positive reviews from critics. Review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported that 83% of critics gave positive reviews based on a sample of 196 reviews with an average rating of 7.4/10.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/10012063-ghost_writer/ | title=Ghost Writer Movie Reviews, Pictures | work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]| accessdate=21 February 2010}} Its consensus notes that, "While it may lack the revelatory punch of Polanski's finest films, ''Ghost Writer'' benefits from stylish direction, a tense screenplay, and a strong central performance from Ewan McGregor." Another review aggregator, [[Metacritic]], gave the film an average rating of 77% based on 35 reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/ghostwriter | title=Ghost Writer, The (2010): Reviews | publisher=Metacritic | accessdate=21 February 2010}} For [[Andrew Sarris]] the film "constitutes a miracle of artistic and psychological resilience."[http://www.filmlinc.com/fcm/mj10/auteurist.htm Filmlinc.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100509011724/http://www.filmlinc.com/fcm/mj10/auteurist.htm |date=9 May 2010 }} [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film four stars and declared: "This movie is the work of a man who knows how to direct a thriller."{{cite news|author=[[Roger Ebert|Ebert, Roger]]|date=24 February 2010|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100224/REVIEWS/100229991| title=The Ghost Writer|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|accessdate=5 March 2011}} Journalist-blogger William Bradley has dubbed it "one of the best films I've seen in recent years" in a review for ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' that dealt with the film's artistic and political dimensions.Bradley, William (22 March 2010). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/william-bradley/the-ghosts-of-tony-blair_b_509269.html "The Ghost(s): Of Tony Blair, Roman Polanski, and A War on Terror"]. ''[[HuffPost]]''. Retrieved 5 March 2011. ''[[The Guardian]]'' said: "Roman Polanski's deft take on Robert Harris's political thriller is the director's most purely enjoyable film for years."{{cite news|last=Bradshaw|first=Peter|title=The Ghost Writer|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/feb/12/roman-polanski-ghost-writer|accessdate=14 April 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=12 February 2010}} Writing for ''[[LAS Magazine]]'', Theon Weber gave the film a 6.8 (of 10) rating and called it "a thriller with topical ambitions; it takes place in a jittery, bomb-fearing Britain and America, often in airports or official buildings, where the weary rituals of security screenings refuse to let the characters or the audience relax."{{cite web|last=Weber|first=Theon|title=The Ghost Writer|work=[[LAS Magazine]]|date=9 March 2010|url=http://lostatsea.net/feature.phtml?fid=7111219124b94db94ce65b|accessdate=5 March 2011}} However, [[John Rentoul (journalist)|John Rentoul]] from the UK's ''[[The Independent]]'', who describes himself as an "ultra [[Blairite]] with a slavish admiration for Tony", and John Rosenthal, from the conservative [[PJ Media|Pajamas Media]], both denounced the film because it was made with financial support from the [[German government]]. Rentoul also launched a scathing attack on Polanski describing the winner of Berlin's [[Silver Bear]] as "propaganda" and a "Blair hating movie".{{cite journal|author=[[John Rentoul (journalist)|Rentoul, John]] |date=26 May 2010 |title=I Was Wrong About The Ghost |publisher=''Independent Minds'' (blog via [[LiveJournal]]) |accessdate=5 March 2011 |url=http://johnrentoul.independentminds.livejournal.com/409928.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819021440/http://johnrentoul.independentminds.livejournal.com/409928.html |archivedate=19 August 2011 |df= }} Still, what the critics did not explain was that although the production company, Elfte Babelsberg Film GmbH, received €3.5 million from the German state,{{cite web|url=http://www.ffa.de/downloads/dfff/foerderzusagen/Foerderzusagen_DFFF_2009.pdf|title=List of grant approvals from the German Federal Film Fund (2009)|publisher=Deutscher Filmförderfonds|accessdate=5 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719010159/http://www.ffa.de/downloads/dfff/foerderzusagen/Foerderzusagen_DFFF_2009.pdf|archivedate=19 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} any major film production within Germany is entitled to apply for financial assistance from the {{Interlanguage link multi|Deutscher Filmförderfonds|de|3=Deutscher Filmförderfonds|lt=German Federal Film Fund}}. Since the assistance is considered a grant, there is no requirement that it be repaid.{{cite web|url=http://www.ffa.de/content_dfff/dfff_leitfaden.phtml?language=en|title=German Federal Film Fund (DFFF)|publisher=Deutscher Filmförderfonds|accessdate=5 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070708175805/http://www.ffa.de/content_dfff/dfff_leitfaden.phtml?language=en|archivedate=8 July 2007|df=dmy-all}} As a result of this funding policy, numerous English-language films have been at least partially shot in Germany over the last two decades, among them ''[[The Bourne Supremacy (film)|The Bourne Supremacy]], [[The Bourne Ultimatum (film)|The Bourne Ultimatum]], [[Aeon Flux (film)|Aeon Flux]], [[Valkyrie (film)|Valkyrie]], [[The Pianist (2002 film)|The Pianist]], [[The Grand Budapest Hotel]], [[The Constant Gardener (film)|The Constant Gardener]], [[Unknown (2011 film)|Unknown]], [[Inglourious Basterds]], and [[Anonymous (film)|Anonymous]]''. ==Awards== {{main article|List of accolades received by The Ghost Writer}} The movie has won numerous awards, particularly for Roman Polanski as director, Ewan McGregor in the lead role, and Olivia Williams as Ruth Lang. ==See also== *[[2010 in film]] *[[British films of 2010]] *[[List of films set in London]] *[[List of films set in New England]] *[[List of thriller films]] *''[[Roman de Gare]]'' (France, 2006), by [[Claude Lelouch]] (who appears as [[Hervé Picard]]), also about a ghost writer. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|The Ghostwriter}} *{{Allmovie title|424212|The Ghost Writer}} *{{mojo title|theghostwriter|The Ghost Writer}} *{{IMDb title|1139328|The Ghost Writer}} *{{metacritic film|ghostwriter|The Ghost Writer}} *{{rotten-tomatoes|10012063-ghost_writer|title=The Ghost Writer}} {{Roman Polanski}} {{European Film Award for Best Film}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ghost Writer}} [[Category:2010 films]] [[Category:2010s thriller films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British thriller films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Fictional reporters]] [[Category:Films about writers]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French thriller films]] [[Category:Films based on British novels]] [[Category:Films directed by Roman Polanski]] [[Category:Films set in London]] [[Category:Films set in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Films shot in Denmark]] [[Category:Films shot in Germany]] [[Category:German films]] [[Category:German thriller films]] [[Category:Political thriller films]] [[Category:Thriller drama films]] [[Category:Summit Entertainment films]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Tony Blair]] [[Category:Babelsberg Studio films]] [[Category:European Film Awards winners (films)]] [[Category:Films whose director won the Best Director Lumières Award]] [[Category:Films scored by Alexandre Desplat]] [[Category:Ghostwriting in fiction]]

revision.text:
The '''Village of the Arts''' is located in [[Bradenton, Florida|Bradenton]], [[Florida]]. The Village covers {{convert|36|acre|m2}} and contains over 200 homes, [[art gallery|art galleries]], restaurants, workshops and studios. Area residents live alongside the artists. Many galleries/studios in this area are also homes, making this restored section of [[Bradenton, Florida|Bradenton]] unique with its many [[artist in residence|artists-in-residence]]. {{TOC right}}
==Village area== The Village of the Arts is a residential and business community contained between 14th Street West, Route 41/9th Street West and 16th Avenue West in Bradenton, Florida, approximately {{convert|50|mi|km}} south of Tampa and 14 miles north of Sarasota. This area of Bradenton originally consisted of 1920's style architecture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.villageofthearts.com/about.php|title=About Village of the Arts|work=VillageOfTheArts.com|accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref> From May 31, 1937 until the site was home to the [[Bradenton General Hospital]].
Some of the buildings used for galleries and homes are as old as 100 years.<ref name="globe">{{cite web|url=http://www.thesaundersblog.com/revitalized-bradenton-brims-with-artistic-flair|title=Revitalized Bradenton Brims with Artistic Flair|work=Boston Globe|accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref>
==Live-work space== The Village is a diverse collection of artists, galleries and fine food. Artisians from the Village of the Arts received regulatory relief from the city of [[Bradenton]] allowing [[artist-in-residence]]s to live and work out of their homes.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://villageofthearts.com/UserFiles/File/Village%20History%20and%20Info(1).pdf|title=Village of the Arts History and Info|accessdate=2011-10-30}}</ref> At one time, the houses in this area of [[Bradenton]] were considered dilapidated and an eyesore. Most have been restored, painted in colorful [[hue]]s and [[pastels]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5AtlK1ddfPk|title=House Tour in the Village|work=YouTube|accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref> and converted into workshops, studios, medical facilities, family activities, galleries and cafes.
==Artistic Media== Village Artists practice their craft in the following areas:
[[Goldsmith]]ing, [[Silversmith]]ing, [[stained glass]], [[altered books]], [[copper]]-pigment work, [[Assemblage (art)|assemblage]], [[collage]], [[oil-painting]], [[quilting]], [[acrylic paint]]ing, [[fiber art]], [[mixed media]], [[encaustic painting]], fashion and custom clothing, [[antiques]] and their restoration, [[sculpture]], [[drawing]], [[photography]], book-selling, [[basket-weaving]], [[re-cycled]] and up-cycled art, botanical objects, [[mosaic]], [[clay]], [[pottery]], [[music]] instruction and performance, [[art]] instruction, [[watercolors]], [[dichroic glass]], [[woodcarving]], jewelery, cut and polished stone work, [[Metalworking|metal working]] and many more.
Many artisans accept [[Commission (art)|commissions]], i.e., work as ordered and designed by a patron/customer. Patrons are then able to become involved in the production of a piece that meets the needs of a specific space in their home or office.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.villageofthearts.com/about.php Village of the Arts.com]
{{commons category}}
==See also== *[[Artist-run initiative]] *[[Artist-run space]] *[[National Cooperative Business Association]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox television episode | title = Ziva David captivity storyline | image = [[File:Ziva's rescue.png|275px]] | caption = Tony (left) and McGee (right) rescue Ziva (center) in the seventh season premiere | episode = 1 | director = [[Dennis Smith (director)|Dennis Smith]], [[Tony Wharmby]], Thomas J. Wright, Leslie Libman, and James Whitmore, Jr. | writer = Shane Brennan, Jesse Stern, David North, Frank Cardea, [[George Schenck]], and Steve Binder | season_article = NCIS (season 6) | episode_list = List of NCIS episodes }} The '''Ziva David captivity storyline''' refers to a series of episodes from the American police procedural drama ''[[NCIS (TV series)|NCIS]]'' surrounding the [[Prisoner of war|imprisonment]] of protagonist [[Ziva David]] ([[Cote de Pablo]]) in a Somali [[terrorist training camp]] and its aftermath. Originally created by then-executive producer Shane Brennan, the story arc first aired in 2009 during the sixth season of the show and continued into the seventh season. Episodes followed the events that originally led to Ziva's being taken hostage by an Islamic terrorist, the collapse of her relationship with the NCIS team, her captivity and eventual rescue, and the ramifications.
Elements of [[prisoner abuse]] and [[torture]] were used for the storyline, though most of the violence perpetrated against the character takes place off screen; producers avoided depicting explicit torture scenes like those commonly associated with the TV series ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]''.<ref name="Lafferty">{{cite web|last=Lafferty|first=Sarah|url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2009/09/23/ncis_recap_truth_or_consequences_|title='NCIS' Recap: 'Truth Or Consequences'|work=Starpulse.com|date=September 23, 2009|accessdate=July 26, 2013}}</ref>
The portrayal of Ziva's divided loyalties to the United States and Israel during this period attracted attention from several Jewish critics and columnists, who discussed its implications.<ref name="galusaustralis">{{cite web|url=http://galusaustralis.com/2009/07/410/jews-in-pop-culture-a-critical-examination-part-ii/|title=Jews in Pop-culture: a Critical Examination Part II|work=Galus Australis|date=July 9, 2009|accessdate=July 26, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Jewish World Review">{{cite journal |first=Elliot B. |last=Gertel |url=http://www.jewishworldreview.com/elliot/gertel_ncis.php3?printer_friendly |title=One tough Jewess |work=[[Jewish World Review]] |date=July 16, 2009 |accessdate=July 26, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Leibold|first=Rachel|title=CBS’s "NCIS" makes "Aliyah"|url=http://www.jweekly.com/blog/full/38095/cbss-ncis-makes-aliyah/|work=[[Jweekly]]|accessdate=August 24, 2013}}</ref> Specifically, the actions of Ziva's father, Eli David ([[Michael Nouri]]), drew widespread debate, and his seeming nonchalant attitude towards his daughter's abuse garnered much criticism for the character. Within the series, it led to her decision to resign from Mossad and apply to become an NCIS agent and an American citizen.
== Background == The character of Ziva David was introduced by series creator [[Donald P. Bellisario]] in 2005 during the third season of ''NCIS'',<ref name=NYT>{{cite web|last=Carter|first=Bill|title=Behind a Quiet Little Hit, a Reliable Hit Maker|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/25/arts/television/25ncis.html?pagewanted=print&_r=0|work=[[New York Times]]|date=October 27, 2005|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref> which follows a team of government agents who work for the Naval Criminal Investigative Service.<ref>{{cite web|first=Alyssa|last=Rosenberg|url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/magazine/mayjune_2011/features/ncis_bureaucrats_with_guns029134.php?page=2|title=NCIS: Bureaucrats with Guns|work=[[The Washington Monthly]]|date=May–June 2011|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref> Chilean-American actress Cote de Pablo was cast to portray the character, who underwent a number of revisions before ultimately being scripted as an Israeli Mossad officer assigned as a liaison to the NCIS team.<ref name=NYT/><ref name="Bobbin">{{cite web|last=Bobbin|first=Jay|title='NCIS' moves on|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2005-07-17/entertainment/0507170501_1_michael-weatherly-donald-p-bellisario-navy-ncis|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=July 17, 2005|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref> She is portrayed as having a vibrant personality<ref name="Elkin">{{cite web|last=Elkin|first=Michael|title='I've Got a Secret,' Israeli-Style?|url=http://www.jewishexponent.com/ive-got-a-secret-israeli-style|work=[[The Jewish Exponent]]|accessdate=July 27, 2013|date=June 7, 2007}}</ref> despite her background as an assassin and being "an extremely skilled interrogator, nearly impossible to break".<ref name="Lipovetsky">{{cite web|last=Lipovetsky|first=Josh|title=NCIS Character Analysis – Officer Ziva David|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/ncis-character-analysis-officer-ziva-david-4885700.html?cat=40|publisher=[[Yahoo! Voices]]|accessdate=July 27, 2013|date=November 13, 2009}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=October 2015}} {{triple image|right|Cote de Pablo (19 September 2008) 4.jpg|139|Michael Weatherly (19 September 2008) 7.jpg|125|MichaelNouriJune09.jpg|170|Actors heavily involved in the storyline, from left to right: Cote de Pablo (Ziva David), Michael Weatherly (Tony DiNozzo), and Michael Nouri (Eli David)}}
Initially rejected by most of the other characters, she is eventually accepted as a member of the NCIS team and as a surrogate daughter figure to team leader [[Leroy Jethro Gibbs|Gibbs]] ([[Mark Harmon]]).<ref>{{cite web|last=Halterman|first=Jim|date=January 14, 2013|url=http://www.tvfanatic.com/2013/01/ncis-exclusive-gary-glasberg-on-vances-loss-zivas-revenge-and-be/|title=NCIS Exclusive: Gary Glasberg on Vance's Loss, Ziva's Revenge & Beyond|work=TV Fanatic|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref> She also serves as a [[Foil (literature)|foil]] for Special Agent [[Tony DiNozzo]], a former Baltimore homicide cop and "wannabe playboy" played by Michael Weatherly.<ref>{{cite web|last=Norton|first=R. E.|title=NCIS: Naval Criminal Investigative Service--The Third Season|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/ncis-naval-criminal-investigative-service-third-509042.html?cat=40|publisher=Yahoo! Inc.|accessdate=July 27, 2013|date=August 23, 2007}}</ref> Early on, producers began to toy with the idea of pairing them romantically but avoided going through with the relationship by dealing them a number of obstacles, namely difficult circumstances and other love interests.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ryan|first=Maureen|title=Why keep 'will they or won't they' couples apart? Thoughts from half of hot 'NCIS' couple|url=http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/entertainment_tv/2009/08/ncis-ziva-tony-cote-de-pablo.html|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=July 27, 2013|date=August 5, 2009}}</ref>
Ziva's upbringing is alluded in her first few seasons. She is depicted as having a somewhat troubled background<ref>{{cite web|last=Martingale|first=David|title=Slowly but Surely, NCIS Rises to Top of Ratings|date=October 17, 2009|work=Star Telegram|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref> with a difficult family history. Her younger sister was killed in a terrorist attack against Israel, and her half-brother [[Ari Haswari]] became a Hamas terrorist;<ref name="Gertel"/> she eventually kills him onscreen to prevent him from killing Gibbs.<ref name="August Interview">{{cite web|first=Mary|last=Murphy|title=TV's sexiest special agent on fighting, flirting and what's next on NCIS (will Mark Harmon return?)|work=TV Guide|date=August 28, 2006}}</ref> Before de Pablo's first appearance, Ari's father—and thus Ziva's as well—is referred to as "Doctor Benjamin Weinstein" before "the series writing staff later Hebraized Dr. Weinstein's name to Eli David".<ref name="Gertel">{{cite web|last=Gertel|first=Elliot|title=TV's NCIS on those Sinister Israelis|url=http://www.americanthinker.com/2013/01/tvs_ncis_on_those_sinister_israelis.html|work=[[The American Thinker]]|date=January 28, 2013|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref>
Shane Brennan replaced Bellisario as executive producer in 2007,<ref>{{cite web|first=Collins|last=Scott|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/nov/17/entertainment/et-channel17|title=CBS spells success 'NCIS'|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=November 17, 2008|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref> and in the sixth season premiere, he simultaneously introduced Ziva's father, Mossad Director Eli David ([[Michael Nouri]]), and Mossad Officer Michael Rivkin (Merik Tadros). Their appearances catalyzed the events that lead to Ziva being taken hostage later in the season.<ref name="Last Man Standing">{{Cite episode|title=Last Man Standing|series=NCIS|serieslink=NCIS (TV series)|network=[[CBS]]|date=September 23, 2008|season=6|number=1}}</ref>
== Development == [[File:NCIS Filming (8 March 2009).jpg|thumb|200px|left|Filming of "Legend"]] ''NCIS'' writers introduced Merik Tadros' character, Mossad Officer Michael Rivkin, as a potential love interest for Ziva in the sixth season premiere, "[[Last Man Standing (NCIS)|Last Man Standing]]". After initial trepidation over how to move forward with the character, and an aborted idea of revising him as a relative of Ziva,<ref>{{cite web|title=Cote de Pablo Interview in Australia's TV Week|work=TV Week|date=January 29, 2009|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref> executive producer Shane Brennan decided to script what he considered to be a [[love triangle]] between Ziva, Tony, and Rivkin for the latter half of the season.<ref name=3-5-2009>{{Cite web|first=Michael|last=Ausiello|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2009/03/05/ncis-shocker-a/|title ='NCIS' shocker: A 'tragic' fate for Tony and Ziva|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref> The story arc, which was planned to end in a "tragic" fashion,<ref name=3-5-2009/> was set to cover the last four episodes of the year.<ref>{{cite web|last=Willman|first=Chris|title=Michael Weatherly Speaks!|work=[[TV Guide Magazine]]|date=May 3, 2009|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref>
Brennan began the arc by writing the two-part episode "Legend" which served as a backdoor pilot episode for the spin-off series, "NCIS: Los Angeles" featuring the hunt for a terrorist; when Special Agents Leroy Jethro Gibbs ([[Mark Harmon]]) and Timothy McGee ([[Sean Murray (actor)|Sean Murray]]) fly to Los Angeles to work with the NCIS Office of Special Projects — Los Angeles team to solve the murder of a marine, they discover that the killing is linked to members of a sleeper cell. Rivkin becomes involved and, rather than working with NCIS to apprehend the terrorists, kills the suspects, frustrating the other agents.
Back in Washington D.C., Tony starts to question Ziva's loyalty when she defends Rivkin's actions, and it is made evident that she is in a relationship with the latter in the closing moments of Part II as the two are seen in bed together.<ref name=Tadros/>
The nature of Ziva's romance with Rivkin became a subject of debate among viewers, and some speculated that it could have been arranged by her father against her will.<ref name=Tadros>{{cite web|last=Mitovich|first=Matt|title=''NCIS'' Preview: "You Are Witnessing the Calm Before the Storm"|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/NCIS-Preview-Tadros-1005967.aspx|work=TV Guide|date=May 11, 2009|accessdate=July 27, 2013}}</ref> Tadros opined that "Rivkin loves Ziva" regardless of the circumstances and acted accordingly from that perspective.<ref name=Tadros/> Despite this, the relationship becomes more ambiguous in the last two episodes of the season as a security breach at the SECNAV's residence leads to the death of an ICE agent and evidence points to Rivkin. Tony confronts a drunken Rivkin, resulting in a vicious brawl between them that culminates with Tony being forced to shoot Rivkin in self-defense when Rivkin attempts to stab Tony with a piece of glass. Despite Ziva's efforts, Rivkin ultimately succumbs to his wounds and dies.<ref name="Aliyah">{{Cite episode|title=Aliyah|series=NCIS|serieslink=NCIS (TV series)|network=[[CBS]]|date=May 19, 2009|season=6|number=25}}</ref>
The killing, and the ensuing events, generated some controversy among viewers. On screen, it causes a rift between Tony and Ziva, as well as a violent confrontation between the two in the season finale. Cote de Pablo described Tony's actions as "almost unforgivable"<ref name=EW2009>{{cite web|last=Bierly|first=Mandi|title='NCIS"s Cote de Pablo talks Tiva tension and takes the EW Pop Culture Personality Test|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2009/05/05/cote-de-pablo-n/|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=May 5, 2009|accessdate=July 28, 2013}}</ref> from her character's perspective despite their being in self-defense and stated, "I think sometimes when people make mistakes, they can be impulsive and judge someone on one particular thing. Ziva isn't overreacting—Tony did kill someone who was a big part of her life—but, at the time, she couldn't see clearly."<ref name="TV Week">{{cite web|last=Willman|first=Chris|title=The Future for "Tiva"|work=[[TV Week]] October 10–16 Issue ACP Magazines|date=October 16, 2009|accessdate=July 28, 2013}}</ref> {{quote box |width = 30em |border = 1px |align=right |bgcolor=#c6dbf7 |fontsize = 85% |title_bg = |title_fnt = |title = |quote = "I've never shied away from taking this character to really dark places. It was the only way I could justify what would happen in the future with her, to show what she went through." |salign = right |source =—Cote de Pablo<ref name="TV Week"/> }} NCIS Director Leon Vance ([[Rocky Carroll]]) agrees to a request from Eli and brings the involved parties to Israel. Eli interrogates Tony and accuses him of killing Rivkin out of jealously, a motivation that Michael Weatherly voiced to have been plausible.<ref name="TV Week"/> Tony, in turn, accuses him of ordering Rivkin to seduce Ziva in order to keep an eye on her, which he does not deny.<ref name="Aliyah"/> Under pressure from her father, Ziva stays in Israel and returns to the Mossad as a full-time operative, taking Rivkin's place on a mission to assassinate Saleem Ulman (Omid Abtahi), the leader of a terrorist training camp in Somalia which also sees her leaving NCIS as well and seeing the Major Case Response Team being reduced to three active members: Gibbs, DiNozzo and McGee. Gibbs confronts Vance about the turn of events, insisting that he still trusts Ziva because of her choice to save him by killing her brother four years earlier. In response, Vance claims that she had only done so because her father had ordered to. The final moments of the episode show her to have been taken hostage and tortured by Saleem.<ref name="Aliyah"/>
The search for and rescue of Ziva was written into the seventh season premiere, but rather than show her in captivity, the writers decided to script the episode from Tony's point of view. This allowed them to shock the audience by opening the episode with Tony strapped to the interrogation chair, rather than Ziva, as well as keep viewers wondering about Ziva's fate. Brennan relayed, "You'll think you know what's going on, but then you'll go, 'Am I seeing things? What just happened?'"<ref>{{cite web|last=Waldman|first=Allison|url=http://www.aoltv.com/2009/08/12/nciss-premiere-will-begin-with-a-bang/|title=NCIS's premiere will begin with a bang|work=AOL TV|date=August 12, 2009|accessdate=August 15, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ausiello|first=Michael|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2009/08/11/scoop-ncis-plans-shocking-twist/?xid=rss-feed-todayslatest-'NCIS'%3A+Tony+and+Ziva+scoop!|title=Scoop: 'NCIS' plans shocking twist|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=August 11, 2009|accessdate=August 15, 2013}}</ref> Within the episode, Tony, under the influence of truth serum, recounts to Saleem the events that occurred during the four months since Ziva's disappearance: the team at first attempted to replace Ziva without success. After becoming concerned about her continued lack of communication, they hacked into Mossad's database and learned that she had been put on the assignment to find and kill Saleem. Gibbs then informed them that the ''Damocles'', the ship the Mossad team had taken, had sunk in a storm and that there were no survivors. Tony subsequently became despondent for some time until deciding that they needed to avenge Ziva's death by killing Saleem. This led to him and McGee intentionally being taken captive and interrogated upon locating the camp through the shipment of the fictional drink, "Caf-Pow!". In present day, he concludes that Ziva is "not replaceable".<ref name="Truth or Consequences"/> [[File:NCIS television prop (19 September 2008).jpg|right|thumb|125px|"Caf-Pow!", the fictional drink used to locate the camp where Ziva is held hostage.]]
An infuriated Saleem demands the locations and identities of all other NCIS operatives in the area, threatening to execute a hostage if they refuse to cooperate. To Tony's shock and relief, Saleem brings a [[bound up|bound]] Ziva into the cell, who is very much alive. Gibbs kills Saleem before he can harm either captive, and the camp is raided by Navy SEALs. In the closing moments of the episode, Ziva returns to NCIS with the team and is welcomed back in the office.<ref name="Truth or Consequences"/>
Subsequent episodes center on her recovery and integration back into the team. The other characters are at first uncertain of her allegiances, and Ziva herself suffers from the trauma of what was done to her during captivity.<ref name="TV Week"/> "Things are different for her with everyone," de Pablo explained. "When she returns, her loyalty is questioned - but, in this season, it will become very clear that she sees NCIS as her family and that her loyalty is really with this family, as opposed to her blood family in Israel."<ref name="TV Week"/> Producers used the storyline as an opportunity for Ziva to resign from Mossad and apply to become a full-time NCIS agent and American citizen, solidifying her presence at the agency.<ref name="Gertel"/> She manages to repair her relationship with Tony, and when confronted she assures Gibbs that she had in fact killed Ari to save his life. However, the latter continues to distance himself emotionally from her.
Brennan had the fourth episode of the season, "[[Good Cop, Bad Cop (NCIS)|Good Cop, Bad Cop]]", scripted to in effect "[fill] in the blanks" left between the season finale and premiere.<ref name="AdamBryant"/> In it, the team discovers that Damocles did not sink in a storm but rather was abandoned after a shootout resulted in the entire crew and one member of the Mossad team being killed. Flashbacks are threaded through the episode, mostly set on the ''Damocles'', showing that Ziva had befriended a U.S. Marine deserter-turned-freelance-agent on board who was among those killed and that Eli later ordered her to continue on the mission despite the risks making her death almost inevitable. Rather than risk the remaining members of her team being killed, as they were both injured in the shooting, she opted to continue alone and as a result was taken hostage. {{quote box |width = 30em |border = 1px |align=left |bgcolor=#c6dbf7 |fontsize = 85% |title_bg = |title_fnt = |title = |quote = "The early episodes were a bit tense - he wanted to embrace her and bring her back into the fold but felt the need to be standoffish. Will he be someone she can trust, implicitly? Absolutely, without doubt. Will he ever be the warm and fuzzy big fluffy teddy bear in the corner? No, not a chance. At the end of the day, Gibbs is a realist." |salign = left |source =—Mark Harmon on Gibbs and Ziva<ref name="Harmon Interview">{{cite web|last=Willman|first=Chris|title=Exclusive: Mark Harmon Tells All|work=TV Guide|date=October 24, 2009}}</ref> }} She becomes a suspect for the marine's death when Eli, in an attempt to prevent her from leaving Mossad, orders her former team leader, Malachi Ben Gidon, who had been on the mission with her, to accuse her of being responsible for the killing. After she is proven innocent, Gibbs angrily states that Ziva is "off limits" to Eli. They reconcile, with Ziva relaying the rest of what happened up to being taken captive. Gibbs then whispers something in her ear and kisses her forehead as she breaks down crying.
Mark Harmon explained that Gibbs, despite being "a huge fan of hers" and the character who "perhaps cares the most" about Ziva, had to be wary of her in the beginning due to the question of loyalty.<ref name="Harmon Interview"/> He improvised the final moments of the characters' reconciliation, and what Gibbs whispered to her became a subject of discussion among viewers. Likewise, de Pablo's reaction to it was not scripted either. Harmon declined to divulge what was said, stating, "That's our secret." These events propelled the idea of Gibbs as a surrogate father figure to Ziva, marking the first time it was verbally acknowledged within the series.<ref name="Harmon Interview"/><ref group=n>Ziva calls Gibbs "the closest thing [she has] to a father" in "Reunion", the second episode of Season 7.</ref>
Following "Good Cop, Bad Cop", Ziva's attempts to gain American citizenship became the main subplot while her captivity is only mentioned in passing throughout the rest of Season 7 and into Season 8. To assure the audience that the seriousness of the character's trauma had not been overlooked, a February episode had her briefly discuss the experience with Tony. "In true NCIS fashion, it's never quite addressed..." de Pablo said. "The way it was written was sort of glazed over, but it was so there. We're constantly being bombarded with new information, or else the characters just wouldn't grow or go anywhere."<ref name="January"/> Ziva is uncomfortable when Tony recommends picking the lock of a warehouse to search it without a warrant, reasoning that doing so would help them solve the case more quickly. She explains that when she was in Somalia, Saleem would regularly attempt to justify his crimes by claiming that he committed them to protect his way of life.<ref name="Masquerade">{{Cite episode|title=Masquerade|series=NCIS|serieslink=NCIS (TV series)|network=[[CBS]]|date=February 2, 2010|season=7|number=14}}</ref>
Afterwards, the subject is alluded to during specific cases, such as when the team deals with a rape victim at the end of Season 7 and an abused wife in the middle of Season 8. In the latter case, Head Medical Examiner Ducky Mallard ([[David McCallum]]) suggests that Gibbs have Ziva be the one to confront the woman, saying, "Agent David has been through things you and I can't even imagine, and she knows what it's like to be controlled."<ref name="Freedom">{{Cite episode|title=Freedom|series=NCIS|serieslink=NCIS (TV series)|network=[[CBS]]|date=February 1, 2011|season=8|number=13}}</ref> Michael Nouri was brought back to guest star as Eli David during the eighth season, and the consequences of his actions are addressed. Ziva is able to forgive him somewhat, and he tries to reach a full reconciliation in Season 10's "[[Shabbat Shalom (NCIS)|Shabbat Shalom]]". However, he is killed in a targeted shooting before he is able to make peace with his daughter, greatly devastating Ziva and prompting her to embark on a campaign of revenge against the man responsible: Ilan Bodnar.
== Use of torture == Ziva's ordeal in Somalia included being tortured by Saleem and his men, but the producers avoided depicting it graphically.<ref name="Lafferty"/> Shane Brennan wrote a cliffhanger for the season finale that briefly shows her in the aftermath of an evidently brutal interrogation; in it, she is limp and tied to a chair, bloody and bruised.<ref name="Lafferty2">{{cite web|last=Lafferty|first=Sarah|url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2009/05/20/ncis_season_finale_aliyah_|title='NCIS' Season Finale: 'Aliyah'|work=Starpulse.com|date=May 20, 2009|accessdate=August 6, 2013}}</ref> Makeup specialists were able to use a significant amount of cosmetics on de Pablo to make her face "nearly unrecognizable".<ref name="SL">{{cite web|last=Bierly|first=Mandi|title='NCIS' season finale: Confused, but amused|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2009/05/20/ncis-season-fin/|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=May 20, 2009|accessdate=March 23, 2013}}</ref> The torturer, later identified as Saleem, casually returns to her cell, rips off her [[Star of David]] pendant, and demands that she tell him what she knows about NCIS.<ref name="SL"/> She does not appear again until her rescue in the Season 7 premiere, where she is [[Hooding|hooded]], "ready to die", and unable to walk on her own.<ref name="Truth or Consequences">{{Cite episode|title=Truth or Consequences|series=NCIS|serieslink=NCIS (TV series)|network=[[CBS]]|date=September 22, 2009|season=7|number=1}}</ref>
Tony and McGee are both later captured by Saleem on purpose as part of the operation to take down the terrorist prison camp.<ref name="Truth or Consequences"/> They suffer an initial beating on being taken hostage, but neither are shown being subjected to torture for information. As the entire premiere is set during Tony's interrogation, ''NCIS'' writers opted to script Saleem as injecting Tony with [[truth serum]] as a means of obtaining information from him.<ref name="Truth or Consequences"/><ref name="Weatherly"/> Glue, which tightens the skin, was put on the actors' lips to effectively make all three characters look sunburned and dehydrated.<ref name="Weatherly">{{cite web|last=Weatherly|first=Michael|title=NCIS's 200th Episode: Michael Weatherly's Top 10 Moments|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/02/07/ncis-200th-episode-michael-weatherly-s-top-10-moments.html|work=[[The Daily Beast]]|accessdate=August 6, 2013|date=February 7, 2012}}</ref>
The specifics of Ziva's abuse are not discussed following her rescue, and, within the series, the other characters only refer to it vaguely. For example, Vance tells Gibbs that "Saleem's men put a world of hurt on her"<ref name="Reunion">{{Cite episode|title=Reunion|series=NCIS|serieslink=NCIS (TV series)|network=[[CBS]]|date=September 29, 2009|season=7|number=2}}</ref> and Ducky states that "she went through far more than [they] originally suspected".<ref name="The Inside Man">{{Cite episode|title=The Inside Man|series=NCIS|serieslink=NCIS (TV series)|network=[[CBS]]|date=October 6, 2009|season=7|number=3}}</ref> Though an episode was filmed to clear some of the questions by showing the events that led up to her captivity,<ref name="AdamBryant">{{cite web|last=Bryant|first=Adam|title=''NCIS'' Preview: What Exactly Happened to Ziva?|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/ncis-preview-ziva-1010834.aspx|work=TV Guide|accessdate=August 7, 2013|date=October 13, 2009}}</ref> it did not delve into her time as a hostage and de Pablo later confirmed that the ambiguity of what had happened during those four months was intentional.<ref name="January">{{cite web|last=Willman|first=Chris|title=NCIS – Up In The Air|work=TV Guide|accessdate=August 7, 2013|date=January 21, 2010}}</ref> Viewers began to speculate that Ziva had been raped while in captivity and questioned whether the plot was too dark for a primetime drama to explore in depth.<ref name="TVO">{{cite web|title=Review - NCIS Season 7 Episode 23 Patriot Down|work=TV Obsessed|date=May 19, 2010|accessdate=July 26, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=NCIS Fanatic Live Chat|year=2012|accessdate=August 7, 2013}}</ref><ref name="dePablointerviews"/> De Pablo did not comment on the subject of her character's ordeal except to affirm that Saleem and his men did "bad things" to Ziva and to suggest that she had suppressed her feelings regarding the trauma in its aftermath.<ref name="TV Week"/><ref name="January"/><ref name="dePablointerviews">{{cite web|title=NCIS Cote de Pablo Interviews at the Paley Festival|date=March 3, 2010|accessdate=August 7, 2013}}</ref>
== Impact and significance ==
=== Personality of Ziva David === When first introduced to the series, Ziva is "a cocky, young kid who thinks she knows it all and thinks that nothing can really touch her [or] beat her".<ref>{{cite web|title=Season 8 Bonus Features|work=CBS|year=2011|accessdate=August 6, 2013}}</ref> She maintains this demeanor over the next several seasons despite some of the hardships she endures, such as killing her brother and seeing a love interest die from radiation poisoning. During the summer prior to the seventh season, ''NCIS'' producers divulged that Ziva would be "a changed woman" after her experiences in Somalia.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ausiello|first=Michael|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2009/05/21/ask-ausiello-2/|title=Ask Ausiello: Spoilers on 'Gossip Girl,' 'Dollhouse,' 'Scrubs,' 'NCIS,' 'Grey's,' and more|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=May 21, 2009|accessdate=August 6, 2013}}</ref> This manifests in her being written as a softer, more subdued character, and, in the words of Cote de Pablo, "more inclined to listen before acting out".<ref name="D'Mello">{{cite web|last=D'Mello|first=Christine|title='I miss the old Ziva' – De Pablo|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/tv/7491998/I-miss-the-old-Ziva-De-Pablo|work=[[Stuff.co.nz]]|accessdate=August 6, 2013|date=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
While it has been suggested that these aspects made her more likeable,<ref name="Gertel"/> the changes to her personality were not universally welcomed, and Jewish critics expressed concern about the choice to "Americanize" the only Israeli regular on Western television.<ref name="Gertel"/> De Pablo herself preferred the more wild and reckless version of Ziva and eventually began to request that she be allowed to return to some of her pre-Somalia behavior.<ref name="D'Mello"/> Gary Glasberg, who took over as executive producer for Shane Brennan in 2011, gave her that opportunity in the latter half of the tenth season, which focused on Ziva's attempts to get revenge for her father's assassination.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mitovich|first=Matt Webb|title=NCIS Boss Previews a Vengeful Manhunt, Finale That Asks: 'How Will Gibbs Move Forward?'|url=http://tvline.com/2013/04/23/ncis-season-10-spoilers-finale-preview-gibbs-ziva-bodnar/|work=[[TVLine]]|accessdate=August 6, 2013|date=April 23, 2013}}</ref>
=== Eli David === {{Main|Ziva David#Eli David}} The actions of Eli David, both before and after Ziva's captivity, and the extent of their reflection on Israel and Mossad as a whole became a controversial matter during the course of the storyline. On a moral level, viewers were unnerved by the idea of him instructing Michael Rivkin, a Mossad officer, to engage in a sexual relationship with his daughter "to exploit [her] liaison position with NCIS, and perhaps to breed him a grandchild".<ref name="Gertel"/> The situation was made more sordid when the new season revealed that Eli had ordered her to continue on her assignment, even after it became clear that her chances of survival were slim; to make matters worse, he failed to rescue his daughter after she had been taken captive by the Somalian terrorists. Rabbi Elliot B. Gertel wrote:
{{quote|What does this say about Israel and about the Israeli family, besides the obvious bid to point to the dangers faced by the Jewish State and by the United States? From the vantage point of the ''NCIS'' writers, do Israelis, or at least some Israelis, sacrifice their children to protect them, or purposefully spawn dysfunctional families for the sake of the state? Maybe the ''NCIS'' staff will answer these questions next season.<ref name="Jewish World Review"/>}}
Harvard academic Eitan Kensky also weighed in on the matter:
{{quote|Instead of the weak, mother-obsessed Jewish male, we have a trained assassin psychologically scarred by her father...For all her strength, she cannot be strong on her own. She demands recognition and validation from paternalistic men in order to justify her life...If it seemed that Ziva's conflict was between two countries, she was actually torn between two men: her father, a major Mossad figure, and Gibbs. After learning her father set her up, she was adrift, not a part of NCIS or Mossad. That is, until she and Gibbs reconciled. "He raised you to be a ruthless, soulless killer," Gibbs tells her, then he whispers something in her ear, and kisses her hair as she starts crying.<ref name=Kensky>{{cite web|last=Kensky|first=Eitan|title=On NCIS, the 'New Jew' Is Much Like the Old|url=http://blogs.forward.com/the-arty-semite/135566/on-ncis-the-new-jew-is-much-like-the-old/|work=[[The Jewish Daily Forward]]|date=February 22, 2011|accessdate=August 5, 2013}}</ref>}}
Cote de Pablo, who has been to Israel, considered Eli to be a sympathetic character despite his transgressions, explaining, "These characters are able to justify [their actions] because they come from a country that's at war."<ref name=latina>{{cite web|last=Hernandez|first=Lee|title=EXCLUSIVE: Cote de Pablo's Major 'NCIS' Spoiler: "The Whole Kitchen Blows Up and I'm in It!"|url=http://www.latina.com/entertainment/tv/exclusive-cote-de-pablos-major-ncis-spoiler-whole-kitchen-blows-and-im-it|work=[[Latina (magazine)|Latina]]|accessdate=August 6, 2013|date=November 5, 2010}}</ref> However, she also considered Ziva's anger to be justifiable as well, as her father "[sent] her away on, basically, what I would call a suicide mission".<ref name=latina/> Within the series, Ziva is able to partially reconcile with Eli and reach an "unspoken forgiveness" for him in the eighth season,<ref>{{cite web|last=Hernandez|first=Lee|title=EXCLUSIVE: Cote de Pablo on Tonight's 'NCIS': "One of the Main Characters Gets Critically Injured"|url=http://www.latina.com/entertainment/tv/exclusive-cote-de-pablo-tonights-ncis-one-main-characters-gets-critically-injured#axzz2YgixfPsP|work=[[Latina (magazine)|Latina]]|accessdate=August 6, 2013|date=November 16, 2010}}</ref> but the show's writers did not begin to redeem his character until shortly before his death in the tenth season episode "[[Shabbat Shalom (NCIS)|Shabbat Shalom]]".<ref name=ib>{{cite web|last=Waild|first=Christopher J.|title=Insider's Blog: "Shabbat Shalom"|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/ncis/insiders_blog/1000235/|work=CBS|accessdate=August 7, 2013|date=January 9, 2013}}</ref>
=== Diplomatic relations between Israel and the United States === {{quote|text=If [[Benjamin Netanyahu|Bibi [Netanyahu]]] comes to visit the White House, and he appears as Ziva, the US-Israeli relationship under the new Obama administration will be enhanced. But if he's Michael, then the highly celebrated Washington-Jerusalem connection is in for some tough times indeed.|author=Steven L. Spiegel, Director of the Center for Middle East Development and Professor of Political Science, UCLA<ref name=Spiegel>{{cite web|last=Spiegel|first=Steven L.|title=What NCIS Tells Us About Obama and Netanyahu|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/steven-l-spiegel/what-ncis-tells-us-about_b_204073.html|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=May 15, 2009|accessdate=August 6, 2013}}</ref>}}
During the first few seasons, storylines related to Israel focus on the "peculiar arrangement" between the agencies "in which the brilliant daughter of the head of Mossad (Ziva David) has been embedded in the American NCIS".<ref name=Spiegel/> For example, the Season 4 premiere involves a plot surrounding Iranian agents framing Ziva, and by extension Israel, for the murder of two FBI agents and a terrorist in their custody.<ref name="Jewish World Review"/> Situations are made more complicated due to her being "stigmatized as the (half) sister of a Hamas terrorist killer".<ref name="Jewish World Review"/> In general, the show avoids creating black-and-white portrayals of the Israeli people;<ref name="Jewish World Review"/> Mossad agents are depicted as effective with justified motivations,<ref name=Spiegel/> but the series has introduced "bad" Israelis, most prominently a rogue Mossad officer who participates in the framing of Ziva in Season 4.<ref name="Jewish World Review"/> Ziva herself is a sympathetic figure who is "unashamedly Jewish" and proud of being Israeli,<ref name="galusaustralis"/><ref name="Jerusalem Post">{{cite web|first=Sarah|last=Honig|url=http://www.jpost.com/Magazine/Opinion/Article.aspx?id=254299|title=Another Tack: Ziva for Prime Minister|work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=January 19, 2012|accessdate=January 19, 2012}}</ref> though she is often more ruthless than her colleagues at NCIS.<ref name="galusaustralis"/>
The captivity storylines took a different route by using the characters of Ziva and Michael Rivkin to symbolize the "two Israels American policy makers have faced over the years".<ref name=Spiegel/> Ziva is "the cooperative and quiet Israeli, who has the technical and personal skills to be of enormous assistance in achieving the mission" while Rivkin is "bright and pro-American, but in this case tough, aggressive, thinks he knows what is best for the United States better than the Americans, is sly and wily, and he doesn't heed the advice of his American counterparts".<ref name=Spiegel/> Both are received differently by the American agents—Ziva is respected and trusted by her colleagues; Rivkin is an object of suspicion.<ref name=Spiegel/> Steven L. Spiegel, Director of the Center for Middle East Development and Professor of Political Science at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] (UCLA), drew parallels between their interactions with their American counterparts and those of prominent Israeli politicians. Ziva, he reasoned, could be likened to [[Shimon Peres]], [[Yitzhak Rabin]], or [[Ehud Olmert]] in that she is able to agree with the American agencies on a more basic, fundamental level.<ref name=Spiegel/> Rivkin, he continued, was more like [[Yitzhak Shamir]].<ref name=Spiegel/>
''NCIS'' writers continued to present the Israeli personalities as capable and justified, though Spiegel suggested that they "[were] too affected by their tragic past".<ref name=Spiegel/>
== Reception == The first four of the arc's eight episodes average between 16.20 and 16.72 million viewers<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/05/12/top-cbs-primetime-shows-may-4-10-2009/18549 |title=Top CBS Primetime Shows, May 4–10 |first=Robert |last=Seidman |date=May 12, 2009 |publisher=TV by the Numbers |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090528034735/http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/05/12/top-cbs-primetime-shows-may-4-10-2009/18549 |archivedate=May 28, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/05/19/top-cbs-primetime-shows-may-11-17-2009/19085 |title=Top CBS Primetime Shows, May 11–17 |first=Robert |last=Seidman |date=May 19, 2009 |publisher=TV by the Numbers |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091005091729/http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/05/19/top-cbs-primetime-shows-may-11-17-2009/19085 |archivedate=October 5, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/05/27/top-cbs-primetime-shows-may-18-24-2009/19466 |title=Top CBS Primetime Shows, May 18–24 |first=Robert |last=Seidman |date=May 27, 2009|publisher=TV by the Numbers}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/05/06/top-cbs-primetime-shows-april-27-may-3-2009/18172 |title=Top CBS Primetime Shows, April 27 – May 3 |first=Robert |last=Seidman |date=May 6, 2009 |publisher=TV by the Numbers |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091005092406/http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/05/06/top-cbs-primetime-shows-april-27-may-3-2009/18172 |archivedate=October 5, 2009 |df= }}</ref> while the last four all maintained over 20 million following their broadcast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2009/10/12/dollhouse-premiere-18-49-rating-increases-to-a-1-5-via-dvr-hopeful-or-futile/30214|title=''Dollhouse'' Premiere 18–49 Rating Increases To A 1.5 Via DVR; Hopeful or Futile?|first=Bill|last=Gorman|date=October 12, 2009|publisher=TVbytheNumbers|accessdate=August 20, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/10/06/tv-ratings-sunday-night-football-greys-win-week-with-adults-18-49-ncis-leads-with-total-viewers/29714 |title=CTV Ratings: Sunday Night Football, Grey’s win week with adults 18–49; NCIS leads with total viewers |author=Robert Seidman |publisher=TVbytheNumbers |date=September 30, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091010132338/http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/10/06/tv-ratings-sunday-night-football-greys-win-week-with-adults-18-49-ncis-leads-with-total-viewers/29714 |archivedate=October 10, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/10/13/tv-ratings-once-again-sunday-night-football-house-greys-win-week-with-adults-18-49-ncis-leads-with-total-viewers/30358 |title=TV Ratings: Once again, Sunday Night Football, House, Grey’s win week with adults 18–49; NCIS leads with total viewers |author=Robert Seidman |publisher=TVbytheNumbers |date=October 7, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323055709/http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/10/13/tv-ratings-once-again-sunday-night-football-house-greys-win-week-with-adults-18-49-ncis-leads-with-total-viewers/30358 |archivedate=March 23, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/10/20/tv-ratings-yet-again-sunday-night-football-house-greys-win-week-with-adults-18-49-ncis-leads-with-total-viewers/30987 |title=TV Ratings: Yet again Sunday Night Football, House, Grey’s win week with adults 18–49; NCIS leads with total viewers |publisher=TVbytheNumbers |author=Robert Seidman |date=October 20, 2009 |accessdate=February 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091023065408/http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/10/20/tv-ratings-yet-again-sunday-night-football-house-greys-win-week-with-adults-18-49-ncis-leads-with-total-viewers/30987 |archivedate=October 23, 2009 }}</ref> Despite the controversial aspects, the storyline received generally positive reviews, with it being called "harrowing"<ref name="Diaz">{{cite web|last=Diaz|first=Glen|url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/ncis/ncis-preview-of-episode-72-reu-31513.aspx|title=NCIS: Preview of Episode 7.2 "Reunion"|work=[[BuddyTV]]|date=September 29, 2009|accessdate=August 11, 2013}}</ref> and "fantastic".<ref name="Lafferty2"/> Response for "Truth or Consequences", the seventh season premiere, was particularly favorable, and it was later listed among BuddyTV's "10 Best [Tony and Ziva] episodes".<ref>{{cite web|title='NCIS' Season 10 Celebration: The 10 Best 'Tiva' Episodes|url=http://www.buddytv.com/slideshows/ncis/ncis-season-10-celebration-10-best-tiva-episodes-50658.aspx|work=BuddyTV|accessdate=August 11, 2013|date=May 14, 2013}}</ref> Allison Waldman from [[AOL]] summarized the execution of the characters' search for and rescue of Ziva:
{{quote|It was supremely satisfying to watch them go back month-by-month to reveal how Gibbs, Tony, McGee and Abby were undone by Ziva's absence...Nothing could top the moment, though, when Tony got to look Saleem in the eye, referred to the movie ''True Lies'', and calmly reminded the guy that his boss was an expert sniper. Then, from behind some weird desert camouflage, you saw Gibbs' eyes and -- BANG -- Saleem was gone. Gibbs took him out with one shot. On the emotional front, of course, Ziva is shell-shocked. She feels undeserving of the rescue, and when she returned to the office and everyone applauded the team for their mission, the vacant look in her eyes spoke volumes. Abby hugged her, doing what Tony wanted to do, but Ziva's not really all there yet. She's traumatized. It's going to take some time to get back to normal. All the more reason why next week's show is must-see viewing for me and the other 20 million who watch ''NCIS''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Waldman|first=Allison|url=http://www.aoltv.com/2009/09/23/nciss-big-time-return-on-screen-and-in-the-ratings/|title=NCIS's big-time return on screen and in the ratings|work=AOL|date=September 23, 2009|accessdate=August 11, 2013}}</ref>}}
Viewers disliked the character of Michael Rivkin, partly due to an attachment to the "will they/won't they" relationship between Tony and Ziva.<ref name=Tadros/> [[Zap2it]]'s Brandon Millman referred to the three of them as "the love triangle of death".<ref>{{cite web|last=Millman|first=Brandon|url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2009/05/finalewatch-ziva-leaves-ncis-but-for-how-long.html|title=FinaleWatch: Ziva leaves 'NCIS', but for how long?|work=Zap2it|date=May 19, 2009|accessdate=August 11, 2013}}</ref>
A portion of the audience criticized the writers for not directly confronting what Ziva had endured in captivity, believing that in doing so they had not properly addressed her trauma.<ref name="Roush">{{cite web|last=Roush|first=Matt|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/askmatt-mad-men-1022932.aspx|title=Ask Matt: Go, Peggy! Plus White Collar, Big Bang, NCIS, and More!|work=TV Guide|date=September 13, 2010|accessdate=August 11, 2013}}</ref> When the Season 8 episode focusing on domestic abuse aired, Steve Marsi from ''TV Fanatic'' commented, "What was most intriguing about the case was not the evidence or the unfolding mystery but the fact that this powerful woman, a Marine martial arts trainer, was an abuse victim. Sounds like someone we know. Ziva opened up to Georgia about similar abuse she suffered and made some inroads, although this could have been extrapolated upon further. It seemed like a prime opportunity for Ziva's character to shine - relating to a suspect similarly strong, powerful, yet vulnerable - but the plot quickly moved in other directions."<ref name=tvf>{{cite web|last=Marsi|first=Steve|title=NCIS Review: "Freedom"|url=http://www.tvfanatic.com/2011/02/ncis-review-freedom/|work=TV Fanatic|accessdate=August 18, 2013|date=February 2, 2011}}</ref> There were also complaints about the choice to partially rewrite the details of the earlier storyline surrounding Ziva's killing of her brother, which had served as her introduction to the series.<ref name="Roush"/>
== Similar use in ''NCIS: Los Angeles'' == Executive producer Shane Brennan left ''NCIS'' to focus on its spin-off, ''NCIS: Los Angeles'', in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|title='NCIS' MEN: CBS TV Studios Inks Deals With Showrunners Shane Brennan, Gary Glasberg|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/04/ncis-men-cbs-tv-studios-inks-deals-with-showrunners-shane-brennan-gary-glasberg/|work=Deadline|date=April 20, 2011|accessdate=August 7, 2013}}</ref> Two years later, a similar storyline and cliff-hanger featuring the torture of two main characters was used for the fourth season finale.<ref name="Hughs">{{cite web|last=Hughs|first=Jason|title='NCIS: Los Angeles' Finale: Sidorov And Janvier Have The Team In A Very Bad Way (VIDEO)|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/15/ncis-los-angeles-sidorov-janvier-finale-video_n_3277391.html|work=Huffington Post|date=May 15, 2013|accessdate=August 7, 2013}}</ref> The characters, Sam Hanna ([[LL Cool J]]) and Marty Deeks ([[Eric Christian Olsen]]), are taken hostage by Isaak Sidorov, a Russian arms dealer who interrogates them for information. Unlike with the original ''NCIS'', Brennan opted to have them tortured onscreen, with Sidorov electrocuting Sam and forcing a dentist drill into Deeks' mouth.<ref name="Hughs"/>
The choice to include the scene drew criticism; a number of viewers were disturbed by the torture and accused the producers of engaging in gratuitous violence.<ref name="Day">{{cite web|last=Day|first=Carla|title=NCIS Los Angeles Finale: Did Torture Scene Go Too Far?|url=http://www.tvfanatic.com/2013/05/ncis-los-angeles-finale-did-torture-scene-go-too-far/|work=TV Fanatic|date=May 22, 2013|accessdate=August 7, 2013}}</ref> In response to complaints, Carla Day from ''TV Fanatic'' wrote an article naming several instances in which television shows featured storylines that included torture, among them Ziva's captivity storyline.<ref name="Day"/> She concluded that what was shown was "just enough to get the point across without overdoing it".<ref name="Day"/>
